Comment: Here's a League game where, again, I've followed Ion's advice and avoided swapping off at the end, when it's a race to mate and I win by one move :-)
My faithful Sicilian again.
and White adopts the fashionable (on Gameknot at any rate) 2. Bc4

! Snapping up the loose pawn and threatening to disrupt Black's kingside
? Better was 14. Rxe8  when 14... Qxe8 allows 15. Nxf6 , when Black has to retake with the g-pawn.  Otherwise 14. ...Bxe8 puts Black's bishop on a bad square and the good bishop falls with 15. Nxf6
? Better was 14. Rxe8  when 14... Qxe8 allows 15. Nxf6 , when Black has to retake with the g-pawn.  Otherwise 14. ...Bxe8 puts Black's bishop on a bad square and the good bishop falls with 15. Nxf6
? Better was 16. Rxe8  (again), when Black can't divert White's attention from the d-file.  White also has to watch out for his N on f3.  He shouldn't allow Black to give him doubled f-pawns.

Defends the f-pawn, pins the R against the Q (if Black allowed White to capture on f6, he would return the compliment of the doubled f-pawns, unless, of course he used his R to defend the Q) and threatens Qc8 , winning the b-pawn: looks good.
side-stepping with check on the open file
forking Q and p
forking Q and p
pinning the R again!
doubling the attack on the weak f-pawn
converting the structural advantage into a material one.  Would this be enough to justify allowing swapping off yet?
converting the structural advantage into a material one.  Would this be enough to justify allowing swapping off yet?

Here, I tried to make 24...Qh1  work but couldn't.  I wanted to avoid a situation where I was chasing his pawns on his 2nd rank while he was doing the same to mine on mine.  His K was slightly better placed to defend than mine.
So I retreated again: he who runs away lives to fight another day!
